metadata.title: Vision for energy material design: A roadmap for integrated data-driven modeling

learning, transfer learning, and unsupervised learning). From top to bottom are data sources, ML models, material attributes, and energy applications. Fig. 2 Roadmap of ML models for energy material design. The red arrow shows the achievable precision (or the precision of labels), and the purple arrow represents the required data scale of material attributes. The large rectangles show the main application scopes (both achievable precision and required data scale of material attributes) of SL (green), TL (yellow), and UL (cyan) methods. The size of the rectangle reflects the scale of the ongoing research on different methods in the field of energy materials. Various representative methods are also presented, such as decision tree and naive Bayes for SL, neural network and nearest neighbors for TL, and k-means and hierarchical clustering for UL. More representative studies are provided in Table 1. Table 1 Representative studies of energy materials with SL, TL, and UL models. It is important to note that the UL method does not require materials attribute data during the training stage, and the scale of materials attribute data is used to understand the physical mechanism of UL. Photovoltaics 2021 [37] Perspective Vision for energy material design: A roadmap for integrated data-driven modeling Zhilong Wang Yanqiang Han Junfei Cai An Chen Jinjin Li ⁎ Key Laboratory of Thin Film and Microfabrication of Ministry of Education, Department of Micro/Nano Electronics, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China Key Laboratory of Thin Film and Microfabrication of Ministry of Education Department of Micro/Nano Electronics Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai 200240 China Key Laboratory of Thin Film and Microfabrication of Ministry of Education, Department of Micro/Nano Electronics, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The application scope and future development directions of machine learning models (supervised learning, transfer learning, and unsupervised learning) that have driven energy material design are discussed. Keywords Energy materials Material attributes Machine learning Data driven 1 Introduction Increasing energy demand has led to a diverse suite of advances in the field of energy materials (e.g., electrodes, catalysts) [1]. Recently, theoretical and computational techniques, such as density functional theory (DFT), have become increasingly essential for interpreting experimental phenomena and providing the mechanistic understanding necessary to design more effective energy materials [2]. These techniques can predict the important properties of an arbitrary compound that are closely related to energy science (e.g., ionic conductivity, reaction energy barrier) before the compound has been fabricated in a laboratory; this has wide-ranging applications such as in material design for energy storage and harvesting [3]. However, high-precision theoretical and computational techniques incur high computational expenses. One recent development is the construction of structure-activity relationships by using machine-learned multi-dimensional fitting in massive material databases [3,4]. As shown in Fig. 1 , machine learning (ML) techniques form an important hub that drives databases, attributes, and applications of energy materials, bringing material design to the next stage of rapid development. Zhou et al. summarized the latest advances in applying ML to material attribute prediction for energy applications, including batteries, catalysis, and etc., which could shed new light on the design of energy materials [5,6]. Current approaches for energy material design includes material data expansions, such as the Materials Project [7], where ML techniques have been rapidly developed. Nevertheless, an in-depth discussion of appropriate ML principles for modeling datasets with various availabilities is lacking. ML techniques are versatile and, after optimization, can obtain predictions that are significantly close to the real target properties at the experimental or computational level. However, the exploitation and implementation of ML in energy material design are challenging, Liu et al. identified three major contradictions in applying ML reasonably and efficiently to the materials community (contradictions between learning results and domain knowledge, between model complexity and ease of use, between high dimension and small sample data), and proposed a domain knowledge embedding ML method to effectively reconcile the above contradictions [8]. The data engineering between energy materials and ML is also a key challenge, the physical insights from large databases with adequate labels (material attributes) remain limited owing to the substantial engineering requirements of data resources (such as data generation and data sharing) [9]. Developing ML models for a few attribute labels is vital for further advancing energy material design. Understanding the relationship between the required data scale of materials attributes and ML models is a major factor in energy material design. Here, focusing on a data-driven perspective on energy material attributes, we deeply discuss the application scope and future development directions of progressive ML models (supervised learning (SL), transfer learning (TL), and unsupervised learning (UL)) that have driven energy material design. Based on the current main application scopes of both achievable precision and required data scale of material attributes shown in Fig. 2 , we heuristically propose future trends in ML models to promote energy science advances that may help ameliorate the energy crisis. 2 Supervised learning with adequate labels At present, SL is a common ML model that plays a major role in the development of the structure-activity relationships among energy materials [10]. The target of SL is to extrapolate a mathematical mapping function between input data (features) and output data (material attributes), usually requiring a large labeled dataset (>102) to achieve models with strong generalization ability. In energy material design, various data sources such as theoretical simulations, experiments, literatures, and open databases have inconsistent data formats and fidelity, as shown in Fig. 1. It is often necessary to predict material attributes such as band gap (electronic conductivity), ionic conductivity, phase stability, coefficient of expansion. As we know, electrode materials need a small band gap to ensure high electron transfer [11], electrolytes need to be electrically insulated to avoid short circuits [12], and for photovoltaic materials, a suitable band gap (such as 0.9–1.6 eV) is required to ensure optimal photoelectric conversion efficiency [13]. In addition, high ionic conductivity and phase stability are required by both electrode materials and electrolyte materials [11,12]. Therefore, targeted material design can accelerate the research and development of energy materials. Based on established data sources, for the pursed material attributes, relevant features for specific energy applications should be exploited in the design of materials with tailored performance. Frequently used features include component and structural features. Liu et al. provided a comprehensive analysis of ML on different material features for material design and discovery [8]. Structural data is scarce compared to component data. In order to eliminate the constraint of structure search space when modeling, Meredig et al. proposed a structure-independent features based on physical mechanisms with ML method, and applied it to the prediction of 1.6 million compositions for novel ternary compounds (A x B y C z ) [14]. Structural features, however, often require structural files, such as crystal files or molecular files containing atomic coordinates. A typical work is the crystal graph convolutional neural network (CGCNN) based on crystal structure developed by Xie et al. [15], which treats atoms as nodes and chemical bonds as edges, and can predict all the material attributes (formation energy, band gap, etc.) of crystal structures provided by MP database. SL methods have many achievements in energy material design and discovery. For example, in the field of catalysis, Sargent et al. predicted adsorption energies between CO and Cu-Al alloys based on ∼4000 DFT simulations by using a coordination vector and a neighbors’ coordination vector, and identified CO2 electrocatalyst candidates, which illustrated the value of ML in guiding the exploration of multi-metallic catalysts [16]. In the field of optoelectronics, based on 7000 experimental crystal images, Kirman et al. trained a classifier for crystal growth by using a neural network and applied it to examine the synthesis of novel perovskites, they found the optimal conditions for the synthesis of new perovskites and synthesized (3-PLA)2PbCl4. They provided the applicability of ML in identifying new optoelectronic materials [17]. In the field of batteries, many researchers have proposed the use of SL to predict the electronic and ionic conductivity of electrode materials and solid electrolyte, etc., which provide more ideas and opportunities for the development of new energy storage systems [18,19]. In the field of supercapacitors, Ghosh et al. used ensemble learning method to predict the cyclic stability of cerium oxynitride during the cycle of supercapacitor, which provided a reference for designing novel electrode materials of high-performance supercapacitors [20]. In the case of adequate input data and output data, SL models can be used to establish structure-activity relationship for features and attributes to meet the needs of specific energy systems. These various applications have demonstrated that SL reduces the computing cycle when designing specific energy materials and this reduction will continue due to the rational utilization of material database in its current stage. However, as shown in Fig. 2, SL methods (green rectangle, e.g., logistic regression and decision tree) remain limited because of the significant requirement for a large material attribute database, where the data generation, collection, cleaning, and sharing involve complex and heterogeneous processes, such as data science, software development, and resource deployment. Based on our best knowledge, databases with both crystal structures and ionic conductivity and high-precision band gaps have not yet been developed; The adsorption energy database of different materials and different adsorbates (H*, OH*, CO*, etc.) has not been formed. Since the SL models require material attributes as outputs, the precision of material attributes determines the upper limit of the model. As more data with adequate and high-precision labels become available, SL can maintain an advantage in the design of novel energy materials. However, a massive database at a high-precision computational level (e.g., coupled-cluster singles and double scheme augmented by a perturbative treatment of triple excitations (CCSD(T))) and even an experimental level cannot be formed in a short time, thereby restricting the application of SL. Additionally, SL may not be suitable for material data with few/no labels. Thus, more effective ML methods must be developed. 3 Transfer learning with few/no labels Similar to SL in use, TL also requires material features (input data) and material attributes (output data) as the data set of the model in the attribute prediction of energy materials. Slightly unlike SL, TL models adopt a strategy (pre-training and fine tuning) that can recognize and apply knowledge learned from source domain/tasks (SDTs) to target domain/tasks (TDTs). To date, several different TL implements can be used in energy material design, one is the transfer of the model parameters and another is the transfer of material features, which have promising applications for overcoming the problem of data paucity. An important factor that promotes the universality of TL is its reuse of the data of the existing SDTs; thus, it does not need to incur the high costs of compiling massive new databases. Here, two directions (“vertical transfer” and “horizontal transfer”) for applying TL in energy material design are summarized. Vertical transfer refers to the improvement in accuracy for material attributes from SDTs to TDTs. For example, for some material attribute that are difficult to obtain (ionic conductivity, energy above hull), we can first collect/obtain a large amount of data through low-precision calculations, and then collect/obtain a small amount of data through high-precision calculations or experiments, and build a TL model based on these two data sets. For example, Smith et al. trained a network on DFT data (ANI-1x, 5.2 M conformations of molecules with an average size of 15 atoms) and then used TL (ANI-1ccx, ∼500k data points) to retrain on gold-standard quantum mechanical calculations for reaction thermochemistry and isomerization on systems consisting of CHNO, which is broadly applicable to materials and chemistry [38]. Wang et al. trained a band gap model (1503 low-precision data) based on CGCNN, which used element properties (group number, atomic number, etc.) to represent component features, and bond length to represent structural features; and they retrained a CGCNN-TL model (64 high-precision data) by transferring and fine-tuning the hyperparameters (the weights and biases for each network layer), and used CGCNN-TL, they quickly identified 75 carrier transport materials, 33 electrode and electrocatalytic materials, 299 power switching materials, and etc. [32]. Horizontal transfer mainly extends the source domain/target domain, for example, in the energy materials design, we can use horizontal transfer to predict different material attributes (from electronic conductivity to ionic conductivity, from adsorption energy to activation energy, etc.), and even the different material systems (organic, inorganic and composite materials). Liu et al. investigated multilayer perceptron models that can leverage electron properties (1245 data) to predict phonon properties (such as phonon band gap and group velocity) for semiconductors using only 124 data points, providing an efficient tool for advancing the design and discovery of thermoelectric and optoelectronic materials [33]. Zhang et al. used an end-to-end deep learning model to predict the adsorption energies between Li-polysulfides and MoSe2 based on 3295–4300 data points, and retained the model based on 500 data points for predicting the adsorption energies between Li-polysulfides and WSe2. This work demonstrated the value of TL in screening positive materials for lithium-sulfur batteries to suppress the shuttle effect [31]. And more recently, Gupta et al. presented a cross-property TL framework, which leveraged models trained on large datasets to build models on small datasets of material attributes. This will promote the implementations of horizontal transfer [34]. Looking forward, it may be possible to predict the formation energy, electronic conductivity, ionic conductivity, magnetism, and other material attributes though horizontal transfer. For now, the initial applications of TL in energy materials have diluted the traditional thinking that research must be coupled with heavily annotated data, and this may trigger new material design paradigms. As shown in Fig. 2, the data scale of material attributes required by TL (yellow rectangle) is considerably smaller than that required by SL; thus, for the same data precision, the cost of data engineering associated with TL is lower than that with SL. This cost saving can be spent on data with higher precision (e.g., CCSD(T)) and experimental level to obtain higher achievable precision of models. However, TL has not yet been widely adopted in the field of energy material design, and it need to be further explored and utilized. For example, further studies must be conducted to extend the source domain/target domain and input feature transfer (such as component features and structural features) to reduce repetitive modeling and accelerate energy R&D and application processes. Additionally, the TL strategy of fine-tuning based on existing models will further reduce the cost of model iterations, both in terms of computing power and data storage. In the future, more efforts will be focused on the improvement of data precision and the rational application of TL to a dataset with high precision and few/no labels to shorten the design cycle of energy materials. At present, the application of TL is limited, only in the network-based ML models. That is, the pre-trained network weight is taken as the initial value of the weight of the next network for fine tuning. It is noted that training a TL model needs to be based on a well-trained model, which may be an unshared model built on large data points; and TL is prone to over-fitting during fine-tuning stage, which requires the participation of experts from computer science or artificial intelligence. Therefore, we also call on researchers to disclose the well-trained models or the hyper-parameters and encourage cross-disciplinary development. 4 Unsupervised learning with no labels Emerging research has shown that efficient and low-cost UL methods (e.g., k-means clustering, and hierarchical clustering) can facilitate the exploration of the vast design space for energy materials. The fundamental goal of UL is to learn from the original data without any output labels and reveal valuable information. Its main role in the field of energy material design is to significantly narrow the scope of screening energy materials and to reveal the underlying physicochemical patterns from the vast chemical space and further guide the design [35–37]. Thus, UL is particularly useful for problems where data labeling is considerably expensive, such as material attributes based on experiments or high-precision quantum calculations. UL has been used in battery, photovoltaic, thermoelectric, and other energy-related fields. For example, to screen solid electrolytes for solid-state batteries, Zhang et al. used the modified X-ray diffraction (structural features) to represent solid-state Li-ion conductors and applied UL to reduce the scope of screening Li-ion materials based on the experimental data, thus alleviating the problem of data paucity and discovering 16 new superionic Li-ion conductors [35]. Similarly, to screen thin-film photovoltaic materials, Wang et al. used the sums and differences of elemental properties (SDEPs, component features) as inputs and employed agglomeration hierarchical clustering to discover eight thin-film photovoltaic materials from ∼2700 unlabeled data and 27 known materials, avoiding a screening cycle of ∼12.1 years [37]. To identify promising half-Heusler thermoelectric materials, Jia et al. applied UL methods (prototype-based clustering, density-based clustering, and hierarchical clustering) to reduce the search space, and discovered a series of half-Heuslers (such as ZrFeTe, ScCoTe) [39]. In terms of material feature dimension reduction, UL can also provide better visual analysis and shorten the length of feature coding to train the model. Ryan et al. used variational autoencoder to transform 3072-dimensional atomic fingerprints into 64 dimensional latent representations, and applied t-distributed stochastic neighbor embedding (t-SNE) to make a 2D visualize for ∼50000 crystal structures, the model can be used for predicting the likelihood of forming novel materials [40]. Moreover, UL can also be used for analyzing the catalytic reaction data, Zhang et al. developed UADDCR (Unsupervised Assisted Directional Design of Chemical Reaction) software to predict the activation energies of the catalytic reaction, where the products contain C/H/O/N/CO. The k-means clustering method that they used can classify the catalytic reactions with similar features automatically, which had a statistical view on the similarity and difference of the reactants, products, and reaction conditions [36]. Compared with TL, UL has a lower (or no) material attribute annotation cost (such as high-precision ionic conductivity and band gap), providing a promising method for mining the extensive evaluation of potential energy materials; the more significant advantage is that UL can aid in the understanding of the relationship between structures/components, properties, and features and in the development of an intuitive understanding of the complex structure-property relationship for energy materials by utilizing massive amounts of attribute-free data. To date, however, large-scale studies have not been conducted to apply UL in the design of energy materials, and therefore, more in-depth UL research is critically needed for the further development of energy science. Whether for SL or TL, establishing an experimental or high-precision computational database for storing various energy material structures and adequate attributes is a large project. As shown in Fig. 2, compared with TL, UL (cyan rectangle) significantly reduces the amount of work required for obtaining material attributes and can be modeled on experimental data; this may dramatically reduce material design cycles for more complex energy material systems and achieve higher precision. Therefore, UL will be more applicable and can be used to rapidly advance energy material screening in the future. Moreover, as additional material attribute annotation is not required, UL provides a new research opportunity for non-energy researchers to participate in the co-development of energy science. Also, since UL is an inference rather a predictive method, it is very useful in screening material data, but cannot establish detailed quantitative structure-activity relationships, which sometimes hampers the development of designing novel materials from scratch. At this point, to enhance the interpretability of ML models, it is necessary to add more physical and chemical factors when proposing material features, so as to discover the important factors affecting material attributes. 5 Conclusions and perspectives Energy material design using ML models, computational methods, and experimental measurements is rapidly evolving and providing a way for track the constitutive relationships from material performances to components, structures, and attributes; data and computer science approaches play an increasingly important role in this regard. From a data-driven perspective, we summarize the recent developments in SL, TL, and UL models that have advanced energy material design and heuristically propose the future trends in ML models, to promote the development of energy generation, utilization, and storage in an economical and timely manner, thus helping ameliorate the global energy crisis: (1) As more data with adequate material attributes become available, SL will retain the advantage of being a useful tool that enables optimal decision-making in the design of novel energy materials. Suitable SL models based on existing databases will continue to provide valuable contributions by shortening the material design cycle. (2) TL and UL are comparable with SL in terms of short design cycles and can significantly reduce the work required for data annotations, thereby reducing the computing and storage burden. As the amount of material attributes with inadequate labels sharply increases, ML modeling will have to be coupled with TL (vertical and horizontal) and UL to achieve significant advantages in energy material design. (3) The combined use of TL&SL (transfer of ML models), and TL&UL (transfer of input features) should be further explored in the field of energy materials. (4) We can build more material attribute data points on the experimental or high-precision calculation level, and use TL or UL to achieve property prediction and energy materials screening.
